results.title: Cate Blanchett: Screen Worlds Spotlight interview
results.brief_description: An interview with actor Cate Blanchett for Screen Worlds at ACMI. Cate Blanchett is an actor who has multiple awards including Golden Globe and Academy awards, and is well known for her roles in films such as “Elizabeth”, “Carol” and “I’m Not There”.

results.title: Animal Logic: Screen Worlds Spotlight interview
results.brief_description: An interview with Animal Logic for Screen Worlds at ACMI. Animal Logic is an animation and visual effects digital studio known for their role on films such as “Happy Feet”, “The Lego Movie” and “Peter Rabbit”.

results.title: Technology/transformation: Wonder Woman
results.brief_description: ‘Technology/Transformation: Wonder Woman’ is an incendiary deconstruction of the ideology embedded in television and pop cultural iconography. Through radical manipulation of the female pop icon, Wonder Woman, Birnbaum subverts and reshapes its meaning within the television text.

results.title: New dance
results.brief_description: Several short pieces in which individuals or groups of dancers work with the idea of ‘minimal choreography’, using simple props such as balls, rods and firesticks to create complicated patterns and rhythms from a few basic movements. The result is a quirky hybrid of circus skills and dance, augmented by some image manipulation in the edit suite.

results.title: You are not alone
results.creator_credit: Jennie Blackwood, Zanthus Films and Anti Cancer Council
results.brief_description: Tells the story of a woman who reports a suspected cancer early and undergoes a successful operation. Dramatically presents the advantages of seeking prompt treatment when the warning signs of cancer appear. The patient is referred to a surgeon who, after the operation, introduces the therapy radiographers who complete the treatment to eradicate the disease.

results.title: The Bedspread
results.creator_credit: Natalie Green, Elizabeth O'Neill and Berry St Film Productions
results.brief_description: Concerns two poverty-stricken women, Mrs Clancy and Mrs Parsons, living in Melbourne during the depression. Mrs Clancy owns a good bedspread, her pride and joy. Mrs Parsons asks to borrow the bedspread in preparation for a visit by a specialist to her sick daughter. This small incident becomes the focal point of the day. Cast includes Janet Robertson, Moira Claux and Kim Deacon. Based on a short story by Iris Simmons.

results.title: Venezuela
results.brief_description: Although rich in oil, Venezuela is beset with staggering problems. Poverty is rife in its capital - Caracas - where thousands of Indians dwell in one-roomed ranchitos. At the opposite pole are the rich with virtually no middle class between the two. The region of Orinoco seems immune to improvement and overall continued development in Venezuela depends largely on increased efforts in the areas of education and economic reform.

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 33]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

This film shows various moments in the Anderson family, including kids’ birthday parties, beach holidays and First Communion at the church. There is some great footage of fashion in the 1960s, particularly beach wear.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 a birthday party, kids eating cake and wearing paper hats
00:01:08:00 a boy blowing vigorously on a party horn
00:02:00:00 birthday boy receiving his gift, a Tommy Thunder toy machine gun
00:02:33:00 girl with fake vampire teeth
00:03:01:00 people sunbaking on the beach
00:04:03:00 the three boys learning to swim
00:05:47:00 snow or hail on the streets of Ballarat, driving through the storm
00:06:12:00 kids on toy bikes and pushing a dog in a pram
00:07:45:00 rows of children in matching outfits at church
00:08:25:00 learning to ride a bike
00:10:30:00 First Communion at church with all the girls in white dresses and veils
00:11:57:00 an older couple walking down the street
00:13:00:00 boys in party hats
00:13:40:00 birthday cakes and frog in a pond (chocolate frog in jelly)
00:14:45:00 more relaxed sunbaking on the beach
00:15:16:00 the three boys in matching bathers (swimwear)
00:15:47:00 picnic under a large red beach umbrella
00:16:42:00 boy in yellow terry towelling hat enjoying a can of Fanta
00:18:55:00 group of kids exploring on the beach and throwing food to seagulls
00:21:03:00 on the slide at local playground
